data.name: label44.ToolTip
data.value:
NOTE 1: A light drop of 60% (1.00 mag) is used to clearly distinguish the drops from a satellite from those of a double star. [ An equal magnitude double star will have light drops of 50% (0.75 mag). ]
NOTE 2: If the satellite is small (<2km), Fresnel diffraction may affect the light drop.

data.name: chkSatelliteLevels.ToolTip
data.value:
NOTE 1: A light drop of 60% (1.00 mag) is used to clearly distinguish the drops from a satellite from those of a double star. [ An equal magnitude double star will have light drops of 50% (0.75 mag). ]
NOTE 2: If the satellite is small (<2km), Fresnel diffraction may affect the light drop.

data.name: panel3.ToolTip
data.value:
To determine the limiting magnitude: 1. The limiting magnitude will, in general, be different for different colors ( blue, visual, red).
2. Find several 'faintest' stars, and retrieve their magnitudes in both visual & red.
3. You should be able to identify each and every star of that or brighter magnitude that is located in the field of the image. If such other stars are not present, the limiting magnitude must be set to a brighter level.

data.value:
To determine the limiting magnitude: 1. The limiting magnitude will, in general, be different for different colors ( blue, visual, red).
2. Find several 'faintest' stars, and retrieve their magnitudes in both visual & red.
